metadata.title: 2D nanomaterials as lubricant additive: A review

sections.text:
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U
SC R
IP T
This review focuses on the tribological performance of two-dimensional (2D) nanomaterials as lubricant additives. 2D nanomaterials have been intensively investigated for tribological applications due to their unique molecular structure and lubricating properties. High strength between atoms within the same layer and low interlayer shear strength make them excellent candidates for lubricating dual rubbing surfaces. Recent developments in using 2D nanomaterials as additives to improve the friction reduction and anti-wear properties of base lubricants are reviewed, and the mechanisms of improved lubrication by these nanomaterials are described. These innovative studies have provided useful approaches to new, high-performance lubricating systems and to increasing the energy efficiency and reliability of existing mechanical systems.
* Corresponding author: hxiao@cup.edu.cn (H. Xiao), liu_shu_hai@163.com (S. Liu)

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Heat generation and dissipation during friction process can waste massive amounts of energy.
Friction-induced wear leads to serious problems including surface damage and reduced performance and reliability of devices. Approximately one-third of the consumed energy in passenger vehicles, for example, is wasted due to friction and wear [1, 2]. Friction and wear critically affect a wide range of applications from conventional bearings, pistons, and gears to micro-scale devices and bio-related devices such as teeth and implants [3-6]. Lubrication is the most efficient way to control friction and wear. Water, animal products, and vegetable oil were used as lubricants as early as 4,000 years ago, as described in ancient frescos in Egypt [7]. Modern lubrication science has, of course, seen remarkable strides as far as our ability to control friction and wear.
There is still extensive research being conducted in search of high-performing lubricants, as
those lubricants that do exist are far from perfect. Lubricant additives are an effective way to improve performance; the more sophisticated lubricants currently available typically consist of both a base oil and additive. The base oil, the main component of the lubricant, determines its primary characteristics. Additives comprise less of the formulation but play a key role in endowing new properties or compensating for disadvantages in the base oil. Corrosion inhibitors, viscosity modifiers, extreme pressure agents, antioxidants, and anti-foam agents among other types of additives have been developed to produce lubricants with desired properties to fit special applications [8-11]. Due to challenges inherent to the current energy crisis, the demand for high-performance lubricant additives with better friction reduction and anti-wear capabilities has dramatically increased.
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U
SC R
IP T
Materials with layered structures, such as graphite and MoS2, are commonly widely applied
as solid lubricants [12-19]. Two adjacent layers of these structures are bonded by weak Van der Waals force, leading to relatively low shear strength, which allows adjacent layers to slide easily against each other under shear force (i.e., providing lubricating effect) [20, 21]. Atoms in the same atomic layer are bonded by covalent bonding, which gives the monolayer structure high modulus and strength. In addition, compared to other nano-structured materials, two-dimensional (2D) nanomaterials have much higher specific surface area. This allows them to cover a greater surface area when absorbed on a substrate surface than other nanomaterials, thus decreasing the likelihood of direct contact with rubbing surfaces and lowering the amount of friction between them [22].
Recently, 2D nanomaterials have been extensively explored as novel lubricant additives [18,
20, 23-29] (Fig. 1). Advances in surface modification technologies have offered new approaches to homogeneously dispersing layered structures in base liquid media. Further, techniques for synthesizing monolayer structure and isolating a single layer from multilayered structures have improved our understanding of the interactions between nanosheet surfaces and other materials. These developments have promoted further research on the tribological performance of 2D nanomaterials as lubricant additives.
Compared to conventional organic lubricant additives like molybdenum dithiocarbamate
(MoDTC), zinc dialkyldithiophosphate (ZnDTP), and zinc dialkyldithophosphate (ZDDP), 2D nanomaterials are superior in two aspects. First, they exhibit better performance in terms of friction reduction and anti-wear behavior [30, 31]. Second, their improved chemical stability results in less harmful emissions and significantly lower toxicity than organic additives[32], making them attractive in regards to environmental sustainability [33, 34].
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U
SC R
IP T
The 2D nanomaterials investigated as lubricant additives can be roughly divided into three
categories: The graphene family, metal dichalcogenides, and “others”. Graphene has been extensively researched both theoretically and experimentally because of its superior mechanical, chemical, and electrical properties [35-38]. The tribological properties of graphene and its derivatives as lubricant additives were first reported in 2011 in a series of publications [39-42]. In addition to its function as an oil lubricant additive, graphene-based nanomaterials are also a useful additive in water-based media [39, 43-45] and grease [46-49]. Effective improvement in lubricating performance can be achieved in various types of base media by adding graphene family nanomaterials due to their ability to separate the contact and to form a protective film on the surface [40, 41, 43, 50].
Metal dichalcogenides are characterized by MX2 stoichiometry and rhombohedral structures.
The most common metal dichalcogenides, MoS2 and WS2, have long been recognized as excellent solid lubricants and lubricant additives [51-54]. Other metal dichalcogenides such as TiSe2 and NbSe2 have been more recently reported to present satisfactory performance as additives after doping [55, 56].
Other materials with layered structure have also been explored recently as lubricant additives.
Newly investigated 2D nanomaterials include phosphate, silicate, and oxide with layered structure[22, 31, 57-60]. Authors and coworkers extensively studied the tribological performance of -ZrP, Y2O3, and their derivatives as lubricant additive in various lubricating medias, including water, oil and grease [22, 31, 57, 58]. As additives, these materials are experimentally demonstrated to reduce viscosity and improve the performance of base lubricants. Unlike graphene-like nanomaterials and MoS2, these nanomaterials exhibit relatively higher van der
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U
SC R
IP T
Walls force between any two adjacent layers and exfoliation of these layered structures is less likely [22]. They reduce friction by their ability to modify fluid flow, which is a new mechanism through which 2D nanomaterials can reduce friction and wear.
In this review, the tribological performance of these three categories of 2D nanomaterials as
lubricant additives are discussed with particular emphasis on their respective friction reduction and anti-wear capabilities and the mechanisms of lubricating performance improvement. The 2D nanomaterials discussed in this manuscript are those added in liquid or grease lubricant. Most contain a few layers or a multilayer structure with thickness ranging from 1-2 nm to tens of nm[58, 61, 62]. Surface modification techniques can be used to control the tribological performance of these layered materials [57, 63]. Improved friction reduction and anti-wear performance have indeed been achieved through certain modifications[63, 64]. In fact, surface modification now serves as an effective tool for designing a 2D nanomaterials-based lubricant additive with desired properties. Popular surface modification approaches for these nanomaterials are also discussed. In fact, surface modification is now an effective tool for designing 2D nanomaterial-based lubricant additives with desired properties. Popular surface modification approaches for these nanomaterials are discussed below, as well as notable challenges to the further application of 2D nanomaterials from the perspective of possible solutions.

sections.heading: 2. Graphene family
sections.text:
To date, graphene is the thinnest artificial material known to the scientific community. It
consists of carbon atoms with a layer thickness of only 0.335 nm. These sp 2 -bonded carbon atoms are tightly arranged in a 2D hexagonal structure known as a honeycomb and endow graphene with
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U
SC R
IP T
unique thermal, electrical, mechanical, and tribological properties such as extreme strength and easy shear capability. Furthermore, its large surface area and layered structure also allow it to readily enter the contact interface of a tribo-pair, preventing the direct contact of rough surfaces and reducing friction and wear. The potential of graphene to reduce energy waste and increase the durability and reliability of mechanical assemblies has been demonstrated when even a very small amount of graphene is supplied between rubbing surfaces [65-69].
Graphene has also been added to conventional lubricants as an additive. Zheng et al.
investigated the effects of graphene nanosheets in oil at a contact between a GCr15 steel ball on an RTCr2 alloy cast iron plate [61]. Wear was reduced 50% after the addition of graphene nanosheets in PAO base oil, and up to 90% on the textured surfaces (Fig. 2). Graphene oxide (GO) is a precursor necessary for the graphene production process; it has multiple carbon oxygen functional groups and can be dissolved in water without necessitating any extra hydrophilic treatments. Elomaa et al. employed GO as an additive in water and investigated its tribological performance between diamond-like carbon and stainless steel [70]. They observed a 57% decrease in coefficient of friction (COF) compared to the control (pure water) (Fig. 3). Kinoshita et al. similarly observed a very low COF of approximately 0.05 at a tungsten carbide on stainless steel contact and no obvious wear even after 60,000 cycles of rubbing tests [43]. Due to excellent friction reduction and anti-wear capability, graphene and its derivatives are often investigated as additives in both oil-based and water-based lubricating media.

sections.heading: 2.1 Oil-based lubricant additives
sections.text:
Most compounds in the graphene family have strong π-π interaction and are innately difficult
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U
SC R
IP T
to dissolve in most solvents. This severe aggregation and precipitation in lubricants has hindered their wider application as oil additives. Workable techniques for dispersing the material in common lubricants are yet necessary. Researchers have made various attempts to improve the solubility and dispersion of graphene compounds without sacrificing their graphitic characteristics. Enhancing their lubricating properties by modification is equally as important as improving the dispersity of graphene nanosheets.

sections.heading: 2.1.1 Nanoparticles modification
sections.text:
Chemical modification is a common approach to resolving the problems described above.
This type of modification can permanently solve the aggregation problem via the selection of functional terminations [71-74]. The termination of functional nanoparticles onto graphene generates a nano-graphene composite with solubility in oil and tribological performance that is controllable by selecting appropriate nanoparticles. Nano-graphene composites exhibit synergistic lubricating properties of both graphene nanosheets and terminated nanoparticles during the rubbing process and can significantly improve the tribological behaviors of contact surfaces. GO is often used as a precursor to produce nano-graphene composites, as the sufficient active functional groups on GO facilitate a reaction with nanoparticles. Graphene can be easily generated by its reduction.
Further, α-Fe2O3 nanorods can be incorporated into the GO structure through the nucleation
and growth of α-Fe2O3 nanorods after the intercalation and adsorption of iron ions on GO nanosheets [63]. The synthesized composite can be utilized as an oil additive and has shown favorable friction reduction and anti-wear capabilities. A combination of rolling effects and a
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U
SC R
IP T
protective tribofilms generated during the rubbing process was proposed to be the primary mechanism of wear resistance.
Zhou et al. developed a one-pot hydrothermal method and fabricated a nanocomposite by
anchoring ZrO2 nanoparticles on reduced graphene oxide (rGO) nanomaterials [75]. Pure oil containing the rGO/ZrO2 nanocomposite showed better dispersion stability than that containing ZrO2, graphite, or rGO after being settled for 48 h. The layered structure and small size of rGO/ZrO2 nanocomposites allow them to easily enter the interfaces of the tribo-pairs. With the easy shearing facilitated by weak van der Waals interactions between its coordinated lamellas, this nanocomposite showed excellent friction reduction and anti-wear properties including a reduction in average COF from 0.263 to 0.118 and decrease in wear rate by 93.6% in comparison with pure oil lubrication. In addition to lower COF and wear, the introduction of new nanoparticles also imparts desirable properties that are innately lacking in the original lubricant: The load-bearing capacity of the newly developed lubricants markedly increases after additive modification, from 100 N to 450 N.
Improved lubricating performance at high temperature can also be achieved by terminating
graphene with nanoparticles. Gong et al. developed a high-temperature lubricant via the deposition of nanosized MoS2 graphene (MoS2/Gr) in polyalkylene glycol (PAG) for steel/steel contact [76]. Compared to pure graphene, pure MoS2, and graphene plus MoS2, the MoS2 deposited graphene exhibited superior friction reduction and anti-wear capability over a wide range of temperatures (from 25 °C to 125 °C), as illustrated in Fig. 4.
Though a variety of nanoparticles have been explored, the easy agglomeration and restacking
tendency of GO nanosheets results in problems with homogeneity or the presence of foreign
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U
SC R
IP T
materials during the modification of graphene compounds. Meng et al. synthesized GO dotted with nickel nanoparticles by chemical deposition [77]. The key contribution of their research was the use of supercritical carbon dioxide (scCO2) during synthesis; they found that with the aid of scCO2, the size of deposited Ni nanoparticles was smaller and more homogeneous and their distribution more uniform in comparison with Ni/GO composites produced without the aid of scCO2. When the as-prepared sc–Ni/GO composites were employed as additives in paraffin oil, an addition as low as 0.08 wt % exhibited superior lubricating performance with reductions in COF and wear scar diameter of 32% and 42%, respectively.
Ni nanoparticles and GO nanosheets exert synergistic effect on lubrication. The introduction
of Ni nanoparticles provide lubrication by 1) making it easier for sc−Ni/GO to penetrate the interspaces in contact surfaces; 2) reducing the restacking trend of GO and preventing damming actions of GO in the front edge of the interspace; 3) covering up the nanogaps on the substrate surfaces and preventing direct contact from friction pairs under contact stress; and 4) helping to bear the load and disperse the stress concentration in the material. This effect is more significant when the Ni nanoparticles are smaller in size and with more uniform distribution [77]. Due to the presence of nanoparticles, the protected film has a higher melting point and greater load-bearing capacity; this in turn helps the lubricant maintain excellent lubricating properties even under extreme working conditions such as extremely high temperatures or extremely high pressures.
The proposed method and mechanism of surface protection is schematically represented in
Fig. 5. It is reasonable to assume that these lubricant additives will continue to expand the possible applications of traditional lubricants.

sections.heading: 2.1.2 Alkylation
sections.text:
Another chemical approach to improving the dispersion of graphene compounds in oil is to
graft alkyl chains on active sites, such as defects and edges, onto the rGO surface via amide linkage. This alkylation modification promotes the stable dispersion of the chemically functionalized rGO in oil, which provides low frictional resistance and a considerable reduction in wear between rubbing surfaces [23, 42, 78]. Yang et al. reported that the alkylamine-modified graphene nanosheets can be well dispersed in organic solvents and form a homogeneous solution [64]. The measured thickness of the alkylamine-functionalized graphene decreases gradually alongside the decrease in alkyl chain length from octadecylamine, dodecylamine to octylamine; this indicates that the introduction of long alkyl chains can help graphene disperse homogeneously in organic solvents. Choudhary et al. applied alkylated graphene nanosheets as a hexadecane additive and investigated their impact on lubricating performance to find that the addition reduced both friction and wear considerably [27]. Mungse et al. reported similar performance in friction and wear reduction when long alkyl chains terminating rGO were supplied as an additive to 10W-40 engine oil [23].

sections.heading: 2.1.3 Other techniques
sections.text:
Apart from chemical modification, the dispersion of graphene can also be substantially
improved through the exfoliation of graphite oxide with focused solar electromagnetic radiation [40, 79, 80]. This innovative method is able to remove oxygen element from the original graphite oxide, which endows the product with hydrophobic properties and allows it to much more easily disperse in oil-based lubricants. Eswaraiah et al. successfully dispersed and stabilized graphene
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U
SC R
IP T
produced by solar exfoliation in engine oil for one month [40]. Considerable improvement in engine oil tribological properties was observed after modification, as shown in Fig. 6. The modification works by preventing direct contact of the two surfaces as the 1-2 nm ultrathin graphene sheet penetrates into the contact, filling up the micro- and nanogaps in the rubbing surfaces to form a continuous lubricating film that helps to reduce friction and wear. The graphene concentration must be carefully controlled to prevent unwanted aggregation and coagulation, which can actually increase wear and friction.
Fan et al. prepared alkyl imidazolium ionic liquid-modified GO nanosheets by a simple
mixing and stirring method [81]. The modified GO exhibited significantly improved lubricating performance in multialkylated cyclopentanes base oil at temperatures up to 200 °C. The formation of a protective tribofilm comprised of graphene and fluorinated oil components is responsible for the reduction in friction and wear. .

sections.heading: 2.2 Water-based lubricant additives
sections.text:
Water is the most common, eco-friendly, and low-cost solvent. It can be given anti-wear and
friction-resistant properties with the addition of lubricant additives. Easy shearing between adjacent graphene layers makes the graphene family an excellent candidate as lubricant additives, as discussed above. However, such potential is based on the prerequisite that the additives are hydrophilic and can be well dispersed in water. GO contains multiple functional groups (e.g., carboxylic, hydroxyl, and epoxide groups) and is indeed able to disperse in water well.
Song et al. evaluated GO nanosheets as a lubricant additive in pure water to find that both
friction and wear were reduced after supplying the additive [39]. Kinoshita et al. synthesized
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U
SC R
IP T
monolayer GO nanosheets and dispersed them in water; the results of their tribological experiment indicated that GO-containing water has better lubricating capability than PAO oil at contact pressure as high as 2.2 GPa [43]. Other studies have further confirmed that GO nanosheets can effectively reduce friction and wear by the formation of a protective film on the rubbing surface when supplied as additives in water-based liquids [45, 70].
For other graphene compounds, the homogeneous dispersion of graphene in a target fluid
(such as organic solvent or water) is necessary to utilize their lubricity. They cannot be directly applied in aqueous environments due to their high hydrophobicity. This challenge can be addressed either by means of chemical functionalization [82-86] through the incorporation of polar groups into the chemical structure or with the aid of surfactants [87-89]. This section describes several approaches to preparing aqueous dispersions of graphene as additives.

sections.heading: 2.2.1 Chemical modification
sections.text:
The termination of end groups with different functions enables the favorable dispersity of
graphene in water. Yang et al. grafted amino-terminated block copolymer on a graphene surface through sulfonation and neutralization to establish a liquid-like graphene without any solvent [90]. This graphene can be well dispersed in various solvents and showed remarkable friction and wear reduction as a lubricant additive. Compared to GO, the liquid-like graphene is more effective in both friction and wear reduction, as shown in Fig. 7. The best tribological performance was achieved at the medium concentration (50 mg/mL) of liquid-like graphene in water.
Ye et al. modified fluorinated graphene using a solvent-free urea melt synthesis method to
improve its dispersity in water [24]. When part of the fluorine on fluorinated graphene was
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U
SC R
IP T
replaced with urea molecules, the amino of the urea altered the wettability of fluorinated graphene from hydrophobic to hydrophilic; this allowed for the application of modified fluorinated graphene in water. Tribological tests demonstrated that this new compound reduced the wear rate by 64% compared to pure water.

sections.heading: 2.2.2 Surfactants
sections.text:
Another way to improve the dispersibility of graphene in water is with the aid of surfactants.
Without any further treatment, exfoliated graphene is hydrophobic. Adding surfactants is a simple and effective way to disperse the graphene in water. Liang et al. reported excellent performance of graphene as an additive in water-based lubricant with a surfactant, (4-(1,1,3,3-tetramethylbutyl) phenyl-polyethylene glycol, designated Triton X-100 [50]. There are both a hydrophobic tail and hydrophilic chain in Triton X-100: The hydrophobic tail is adsorbed on the graphene, leaving the hydrophilic chain in the water. The hydrophilic ends of the surfactant repel each other, producing steric repulsion force and preventing the stacking and aggregation of graphene so that it stably and thoroughly disperses in water. Experimental results demonstrated that adding Triton X-100 gives lubricants with graphene additives a 81.3% and 61.8% reduction in COF and diameter of wear scar diameter, respectively [50], as shown in Fig. 8.
Uddin et al. compared the dispersion stability of graphene after the addition of both ionic
(sodium dodecyl benzene sulfonate (SDBS)) and non-ionic surfactants (Triton X-100) [91]. They observed the formation of functionalized graphene in the presence of surfactants to find notable differences in the resulting thickness of functionalized graphene. The best dispersion stability of graphene in water was achieved by adding SDBS at a concentration of 1.5 mg ml −1 .

Other surfactants which can be used to improve the dispersity of graphene in water include
sodium dodecylbenzene sulfonate, cetyltrimethylammonium bromide, and tetrabutylammonium hydroxide [92]. They can successfully be intercalated in both GO and rGO to stabilize the structure of graphene nanosheets and enhance the wettability of the graphene surface. A stabilized graphene dispersion in water with a concentration as high as 0.3 mg/mL was produced with the assistance of sodium cholate as a surfactant and low-power, long-term sonication [87]. The prepared dispersions can be readily used as a source of water-soluble graphene, which may be a highly effective lubricant additive. Table 1 provides a summary of previous research focusing on the tribological performance of graphene family nanomaterials as lubricant additives.

sections.heading: 3. Transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDCs)
sections.text:
TMDCs are a structurally and chemically well-defined family with a chemical formula of
MX2, where M stands for the transition metal element and X represents a chalcogen (S, Se, or Te). The 2D morphology of MX2 materials lends them low shear resistance to any applied shear stress and decreases friction at the interface. MoS2 is a typical representative TMDC which has garnered a great deal of research interest.

sections.heading: 3.1 Effect of morphology
sections.text:
Vattikuti et al. synthesized MoS2 nanoflowers and nanosheets and compared their lubricating
effects [93]. The nanosheets exhibited superior anti-wear and friction-reducing properties as a lubrication additive in engine oil compared to the nanoflowers. The average COF and wear scar size with the nanosheet additive was significantly reduced compared to those with the nanoflower
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U
SC R
IP T
additive, altogether indicating that nanosheet structure is a better lubricant additive than nanoflower structure; the nanosheets better assisted the formation of a protective tribofilm on the rubbing surface. Weak van der Waals force and repulsive interaction due to Coulombic effect in nanosheets are responsible for the formation of tribofilm [25, 94]. Three-dimensional topography examination confirmed the formation and adherence of a tribofilm at the counter parts having enhance the tribological properties of the lubricant [93].
Although multiple studies have verified the effectiveness of MoS2 and WS2 as lubricant
additives, the factors influencing their tribological behavior have not been fully revealed. The literature contains several contradictory reports. After careful comparison of the tribological properties of seven TMDCs as additives in PAO oil, including MoS2 and WS2 materials with different micro- and nano-structures and different particle sizes, Kogovšek et al. confirmed that size has less impact on tribological performance than the particle material; morphology even has negligible influence [95]. Dassenoy and co-workers studied the effects of size and morphology of inorganic fullerene-like MoS2 nanoparticles on the lubricating performance of PAO [96, 97]. They found that size of MoS2 exerts little impact on friction while spherical MoS2 exhibits better performance in wear reduction than hexagonal MoS2 [96]. Compared to size and morphology, structure defects were reported to be more significant in tribofilm formation and friction reduction because they facilitate the exfoliation of MoS2 nanoparticles [96, 97]. The same researchers investigated the behavior of a single MoS2nanoparticle under pressure and shear via in-situ TEM characterization, and their results have contributed to a better understanding of nanoparticle lubrication mechanisms [98, 99]. Further in-depth studies are yet warranted to explore the impact factors of TMDCs on their lubrication performance.

sections.heading: 3.2 Task specific applications
sections.text:
New challenges in lubricants design include extreme working conditions such as high
temperatures, high loads, high speeds, and high contact pressures, under which lubricants must have optimal thermal stability and anti-impact properties to function properly. WS2 and MoS2 have particularly advantageous thermal stability; they can achieve low COF even at high temperature and extremely high pressure.
An et al. found that the COF of a hard alloy-on-carbon steel contact under WS2 mixed base
oil lubrication does not change much in a thermal environment when temperature reaches about 400 °C [100]. However, COF increases rapidly and fluctuates vigorously when MoS2 is applied as an additive. At temperatures above 400°C, the decomposition of WS2 into metal and sulfur is less intensive than MoS2, indicating that WS2 has better thermal stability.
Shi et al. reported that MoS2 and Ti3SiC2 produced synergetic lubrication for self-lubricating
composites with the NiAl matrix over a wide range of temperatures from room temperature to 800 °C [101]. The reducing effect of MoS2 additive on COF was more significant at temperatures below 400 °C, whereas Ti3SiC2 played a primary role at higher temperatures. As the temperature increased, the MoS2 was squeezed out gradually due to thermal stress and spread evenly on the worn surfaces. s oxidation progressed during the sliding process, a compacted oxide layer containing abundant Mo-Ti-Si-Oxides was found to form on the interfaces, preventing the direct contact of frictional counterparts. As temperature continued to increase, the Mo content decreased due to the destruction and detachment of the loosely-structured Mo-Ti-Si-Oxides layer, resulting in an increase in TiO2 and SiO2 on the worn surface with significant anti-friction effect [101].

EP TE

These unique and useful lubricity properties enable materials containing TMDCs to endure and function well under extreme working conditions.
The excellent tribological properties of MX2 nanomaterials are derived from a chemical
tribofilm generated through the reaction of MX2 and the metal substrate during the rubbing process. This was confirmed by XPS and FIB/SIMS analyses of the sliding surfaces where a large amount of W was found when WS2 was used as additive [102]. In the same experiments, the mean Hertz contact pressure reached 0.94 GPa. A complicated model was proposed to describe the composition and structure of the tribofilm (Fig. 9) and to explain the reduction in friction under high contact pressure. In addition to a protective tribofilm, squashed WS2 nanosheets filled the concave sites leading to a smoother surface, which caused a leveling effect and decreased boundary friction [102]. The MX2 nanomaterials were also reported to fill the concave areas and gaps on the surface, leading to a smoother surface and lower friction [55, 103].

sections.heading: 3.3 Limitations
sections.text:
There are obstacles preventing the further application of MX2 nanomaterials as additive to a
wider range. For example, the application of WS2 is limited due to its high density and aggregation in base oil. MoS2 features much better dispersion but its load-bearing capacity is low when it is used individually. A large amount of MoS2 (~15-40 wt %) is usually added to the substrate to reduce the COF. This large quantity of such soft material further impairs the mechanical properties of the matrix [104]. This issue can be resolved by supplying an appropriate combination of several materials. Graphene possesses excellent mechanical properties and is a good option; other ceramics such as SiC, Al2O3, WC, or TiC can also be added to improve the
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U
SC R
IP T
strength of lubricants [105-107]. Hybrids of different 2D materials as lubricant additives can either enhance the already existing properties of base fluids, mitigate disadvantages in the original lubricant, or impart new properties that the lubricant innately lacks.
The preparation of TMDCs with proper size and morphology is another obstacle preventing
the further application of these 2D nanomaterials as practical lubricant additives. Research has continually shown thatMoS2performance is strongly dependent on the material’s structure[108, 109]. Controllable synthesis of TMDCs with specific size and morphology is necessary to design an additive with desirable properties. Some synthesis methods have been reported, but systematic research on size and thickness control is still lacking [110, 111]. Complexity and high cost in the preparation of these 2D nanomaterials are also problematic issues [32].
Despite these challenges, the excellent tribological properties and thermostability of WS2 and
MoS2 prompted us to further investigate their application as high-temperature oil additives. Table 2 provides a summary of experimental results concerning TMDC nanosheets as lubricant additives.

sections.heading: 4. Other nanomaterials with layered structure
sections.text:
The fluid drag of a lubricant can act on the sliding surface and affect the viscosity [15, 16].
The viscosity of a lubricant can be controlled by adding various additives provided that said additives can change the flow and fluid drag of the lubricant. The 2D nanosheet structures can align in the fluid direction, leading to changes in the mass and heat transfer of the fluid at localized areas [18] which subsequently affects the lubricant viscosity and fluid drag [14, 17].
α-ZrP is a 2D nanostructured compound with such properties. In a series of previous studies,
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U
SC R
IP T
we explored the feasibility of using α-ZrP nanoplatelets as viscosity modifier in both oil-based and water-based lubricants [22, 31, 57]. With the presence of this additive in base mineral oil or water, COF was reduced by 65% and 91%, respectively [22]. The possible mechanisms responsible for this include viscosity modification induced by α-ZrP nanosheets and interaction effects between the lubricant molecules and α-ZrP solid surface. The 2D nanostructure promotes the α-ZrP to orderly align under normal pressure, which subsequently decreases the momentum transfer between fluid layers and reduces the viscosity of the lubricant.
More interestingly, interspacing of two adjacent α-ZrP layers can be controlled by chemical
modifications such as amine intercalation [57]. The intercalation of amine groups increases the interspace between ZrP layers to varying extent when amines with different carbon chain length are supplied, endowing the lubricant with varying levels of viscosity. This may represent a valuable new approach to manufacturing lubricants with tailored or desired viscosity to fit different applications. The lubricant viscosity can also be adjusted by using α-ZrP with various interspaces. Previous studies have reported reduction in friction by up to 60% after adding amine intercalated α-ZrP nanosheets in mineral oil [57].
The presence of a tribofilm was confirmed by elementary analysis when α-ZrP was added as
a lubricant additive [31, 112]. Under boundary lubrication, these 2D nanomaterials entered the contact area to enable shearing effect while reducing friction and wear [31]. Chen et al. synthesized α-ZrP and copper zirconium phosphate hydrate (Cu-α-ZrP), which has a similar layered structure to α-ZrP, as additives for lithium grease [112]. Both α-ZrP and Cu-α-ZrP outperformedMoS2 additive in regards to friction reduction and anti-wear capability (Fig. 10).
There are a number of other layered-structure zirconium phosphate materials in addition to
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U
SC R
IP T
ZrP that have excellent lubricating properties in oil. Liu et al. synthesized a new type of zirconium phosphate, ZrPO4-DES8, and successfully applied it in as an additive to mineral oil [59]. In a comparison to α-ZrP, MoS2, and graphite, ZrPO4-DES8 exhibits comparable anti-wear behavior with α-ZrP. The wear scar diameters of worn balls under α-ZrP and ZrPO4-DES8 lubrication are smaller than those under MoS2 and graphite.
In addition to zirconium phosphates, oxide and silicate with layered structures can serve as
excellent lubricant additives [58, 60, 113]. The effect of rheological modifications has been reported in lubricants with Y2O3 as additive [58], where the viscosity of mineral oil decreased in a non-Einstein-like manner after the addition of Y2O3 nanosheet additive. The effective reduction in friction by Y2O3 was attributed to the ordered inclination of these nanosheets. A concentration of 0.1 wt % of Y2O3 nanosheet additive was found to reduce viscosity by ~5% and friction by as much as ~40%.
Xu et al. synthesized α-layered sodium disilicate and used it as an additive in liquid paraffin
to decrease both friction and wear [113]. In a later study, Chen et al. investigated the effects of a combination of layered α-ZrP and α-layered sodium disilicate on the lubrication performance of mineral oil [60]. The wear scar diameters of worn steel balls indicated that this mixture is the most powerful additive in terms of wear reduction compared to any other ingredient. A synergetic mechanism was proposed to explain the excellent performance of the combination.
A summary of the tribological performance of several other 2D nanomaterials (excluding
graphene family and TMDCs) investigated as lubricant additives is provided in Table 3.
5. Role of 2D materials in friction and wear reduction mechanisms
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U
SC R
IP T
Numerous studies have been devoted to understanding the underlying mechanisms of 2D
materials as lubricant additives in effort to promote their wider application. Generally, the evolution of the protection of the lubricants can be divided into four aspects: 1) Entering the contact area of sliding surfaces; 2) forming a tribofilm; 3) filling the pits and gaps of the contact area; and 4) affecting the fluid drag and viscosity. The four proposed mechanisms are schematically expressed in Fig. 11. The 2D materials discussed above play a key role in these processes.

sections.heading: 5.1 Entering the contact area of sliding surfaces and providing efficient lubricating
sections.text:
2D materials have a sheet shape and small size allowing them to easily enter into the rubbing
contact. The introduction of nanoparticles in 2D materials further enhances their penetration into the interspaces of contact surfaces, which is what makes lubrication possible. When two contacting surfaces rubs against each other under normal force, the 2D nanomaterials in the contact area are subjected to normal pressure as well. The relative motion of the contacting surfaces supplies a shear stress to these materials. As a result, the easy shearing of interlayers in the multilayer 2D material forms a sliding system with the rubbing contact[20, 21]. Compared to hard contact, friction force in the sliding system is much lower, leading to effective lubrication.

sections.heading: 5.2 Tribofilm formation
sections.text:
The formation of a tribofilm occurs at the contact area of sliding surfaces in two stages of
lubrication. At the initial stage, high surface energy and easy shearing allow them to easily adsorb onto the surface of the substrate to form a conformal protective film (physical film) in the absence of any chemical reactions. In this stage, the protective film mainly severs to separate the two contacting surfaces. It prevents direct contact between the two sliding surfaces and reduces the
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U
SC R
IP T
friciton and wear. The physical film ruptures as the sliding proceeds. A large amount of heat is generated at this time and spurs on a tribochemical reaction between the lubricant and substrate. A new tribofilm formed from the tribochemical reaction appears and gradually replaces the physical film. This film is not only found on the localized contact surfaces but also in the matrix of the substrate, which improves the tribological performance considerably [102].

sections.heading: 5.3 Filling the concave areas and gaps
sections.text:
Due to inherently limited manufacturing techniques, no tribopair is completely smooth. The
interface is uneven at the micro scale. Macro-asperities can produce high contact pressure during rubbing process. 2D nanomaterials, especially those anchored with nanoparticles, can fill in concave areas on the rubbing surfaces to smooth them [40, 55, 103]. A smoother surface pocesses less asperities and creates a reduction in localized contact pressure. Lower pressuredecreases the likelihood of plastic deformation, which is the origin of wear. In addition, 2D nanomaterials in the convave areas help to form a continuous oil film which further enhances the lubrication [55]. The instantaneous high temperature generated during sliding can even melt the nanoparticles to repair defects in the sliding surface and reduce the friction and wear.

sections.heading: 5.4 Affecting the fluid drag and viscosity
sections.text:
Under hydrodynamic lubrication conditions, where two rubbing surfaces are fully separated
by a hydrodynamic flow, viscosity is the dominating factor in the friction force and load-bearing capacity of the lubricant. The viscosity of a lubricant is dependent on fluid flow and fluid drag, so any additive that can affect these two factors may be effective in hydrodynamic lubrication conditions. Under a normal load, 2D nanomaterials align orderly in the fluid direction leading to decreased momentum transfer between adjacent fluid layers and a reduction in viscosity.
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U
SC R
IP T
Intercalation of 2D nanomaterials with amine molecules effectively controls the interspacing between any two adjacent nanosheets [57], which can be controlled to fine tune the fluid drag and viscosity.

sections.heading: 5.5 Other possible roles
sections.text:
Apart from the functions mentioned above, 2D materials as lubricant additives play other
roles in improving tribological performance. Some 2D materials such graphene have been proven impervious to liquids (e.g., water) and gases (e.g., oxygen) due to theirhigh chemical stability [114]. The adsorption of such materials on a substrate can help to prevent chemical attack from the lubricant or other active elementsin the system, thus slowing down corrosion and oxidation to the material and further reducing wear on the sliding surface.

sections.heading: 6. Summary and outlook
sections.text:
As human exploration continues to move into new frontiers such as deep seas and outer space,
more and more pieces of equipment and machinery will need to be lubricated under extreme conditions such as high temperature, high pressure, high relative motion speed, and high vacuum. Next-generation lubricants must possess anti-thermal, anti-pressure, anti-corrosion, and anti-high speed properties, among others. Supplying additives is a simple, economic, and effective way to improve lubricants for use in extreme conditions. 2D materials are of interest to researchers due to their unique structure and friction and wear reduction performance, but their application is limited due to their poor dispersion and stability in lubricants (especially for the graphene family). Modification and functionalization treatments for enhanced dispersity in base lubricating liquid are necessary. Modification of the 2D nanomaterials can also endow the lubricants with new
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U
SC R
IP T
capabilities such as thermal stability and improved lubricating ability, which is equally important as dispersity. Oriented design is a key factor in developing next-generation 2D nanomaterial-based lubricant additives. A comprehensive understanding of the effect (and precise mechanism) of modification on tribological behaviors is necessary to ensure successful design. Attempts to explore new ways to modify 2D nanomaterials to equip them with desired properties has resulted in the development of several novel additives. However, there have been fewer effective modifications in this regard than there have been to improve dispersity. Systematic study on this topic is of great importance in securing next-generation lubricants.
The tribofilm formed in the presence of 2D nanomaterials during the rubbing process is one
of the main reasons for improved lubricity. The chemical composition of a given tribofilm can be revealed via elementary analysis, but it is very difficult to precisely determine the physical and chemical reactions occurring during rubbing because the tribofilm usually contains complicated composites. In other words, the mechanism of tribofilm formation is not fully understood. More studies on tribofilm formation may help in establishing a better and more comprehensive understanding of this type of lubrication.
Various mechanisms have been proposed to explain the friction and wear reduction caused by
2D nanomaterials. In most cases, the synergic effects of more than one mechanism produce the final results. The synergy of different mechanisms and the contribution of any individual mechanism remain unclear. Further research on the interaction of additives with lubricants, the formation of tribofilms, and physicochemical reactions on tribo-pair surfaces are still needed. Studies on these subjects may elucidate the lubricating mechanism with 2D nanomaterial additives and further the development of controllable modification and functionalization approaches for
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U
SC R
IP T
these additives.
A variety of 2D nanomaterials have been added to working lubricants as additives to improve
lubrication performance. Typically, only one type of such material is added at a time. Researchers have just begun to explore combinations of two or more 2D materials as lubricant additives. The variety, concentration, and individual properties of each additive may exert significant impact on the tribological behavior of the resulting lubricants; both synergistic and counteracting effects are possible. Experimental evidence of different additive combinations is needed.
Due to manufacturing limitations, it is very difficult to produce 2D nanomaterials with a
specific number of layers. For example, most graphene that is currently obtainable is actually comprised of mixtures of graphene with different layers. This makes it very challenging, if not impossible, to compare different graphene in regards to lubrication performance. Further advancements in the manufacturing process will bring new knowledge regarding the impact of graphene layers on tribological behaviors, which will make customized graphene with designated layers and properties possible.
The indexes of a good-quality lubricant are generally considered to be COF and wear. As the
demand for task-specific lubricants grows, representative properties such as load-bearing capability, thermal stability, and vacuum resistance should be taken into consideration when evaluating lubricant performance.

metadata.abstractText: This review focuses on the tribological performance of two-dimensional (2D) nanomaterials as lubricant additives. 2D nanomaterials have been intensively investigated for tribological applications due to their unique molecular structure and lubricating properties. High strength between atoms within the same layer and low interlayer shear strength make them excellent candidates for lubricating dual rubbing surfaces. Recent developments in using 2D nanomaterials as additives to improve the friction reduction and anti-wear properties of base lubricants are reviewed, and the mechanisms of improved lubrication by these nanomaterials are described. These innovative studies have provided useful approaches to new, high-performance lubricating systems and to increasing the energy efficiency and reliability of existing mechanical systems. * Corresponding author: hxiao@cup.edu.cn (H. Xiao), liu_shu_hai@163.com (S. Liu) ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT
